titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nine Mile Run Greenway Project Records, 1945-2005 AIS.2006.19A
titlestmt.author: Nickie Puit.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:56:56 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Nine Mile Run Greenway Project Records
did.abstract: The Nine Mile Run Greenway Project was a brownfield reclamation project between 1995-2000 in the City of Pittsburgh, Pa. The project was created and coordinated by Reiko Goto, Bob Bingham, and Tim Collins of Carnegie Mellon University's STUDIO for Creative Inquiry. The records contain material that documents the Nine Mile Run area's transformation from a brownfield site to a usable urban space that includes both housing and natural environments.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Nine Mile Run Greenway Project Records consist of planning and outreach materials related to the brownfield redevelopment of the Nine Mile Run area. This stream, which is situated in the City of Pittsburgh, flows into the Monongahela River across from the borough of Homestead. The project lasted between 1995 and 2000 under the direction of Tim Collins and Reiko Goto, who were fellows at Carnegie Mellon University's STUDIO for Creative Inquiry at the time.

Nine Mile Run is a historic stream valley identified by Frederick Law Olmstead, Jr. in 1910 for its beauty as well as its wastewater. By 1928, the valley was selected by influential Pittsburghers for a city park but was subsequently purchased by a steel industry slag disposal firm, the Homestead Steel Company. Between 1930 and 1970 this area was used as a disposal location by Pittsburgh-area mills resulting in a 21-story high pile of slag, a by-product of steel making. The pile covered 238 acres along Nine Mile Run from the Squirrel Hill Tunnel to the Monongahela River shore.

In 1997 the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) of the City of Pittsburgh acquired the site from Duquesne Slag, a subsequent owner, and proposed to build 1,200 residential housing units and develop 100 acres of public space. The site's entire surface area was projected to be surrounded by a contiguous public space along the stream from Frick Park to the Monongahela River. This 238 acre acquisition is the largest in history of the Urban Redevelopment Authority and the project included the largest stream restoration in the United States by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.

The redevelopment of the Nine Mile Run area was a collaborative effort between artists, scientists, engineers, historians, and planners in conjunction with the STUDIO for Creative Inquiry, a research center in the College of Fine Arts at Carnegie Mellon University. The general objective of the project was to develop a transferable model for use in reclaiming other urban brownfield sites.

At the close of the redevelopment process the environment was beginning to show signs of cleaner water. For the first time in 100 years three game fish (smallmouth bass, striped bass, and sauger) were found in the creek along with several other species of minnows and crayfish. The remediation of this area did not end with the project however; in the spring of 2001 the Nine Mile Run Watershed Council was created with the responsibility of conserving Nine Mile Run. The Nine Mile Run Watershed Council consists of both the City of Pittsburgh and upstream community members.

The two major actors in this project were Tim Collins and Reiko Goto. Collins is an artist-research fellow at the STUDIO for Creative Inquiry at Carnegie Mellon University. His academic interests are focused around art and environmental change which can be seen in this project and, more recently, 3 Rivers 2nd Nature, both of which he co-directed with Reiko Goto. Goto's academic interests focus on ecological art projects, which can encompass both redevelopment and installation works.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Nine Mile Run Greenway Project Records consist of correspondence, reports, financial records, minutes, outreach materials, journal articles, workshop planning and implementation files, photographic materials, recorded interviews and meetings, moving image recordings of tours and programs, and maps. The material mainly dates between 1995-2000.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Nine Mile Run Greenway Project Records, 1945-2005, AIS.2006.19A, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Nine Mile Run Greenway Project Records, 1945-2005, AIS.2006.19A, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Nickie Puit from January-June 2013.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into 11 series:
Series II. Research Data and Reports Collected
Series VI. Outreach Presentations and Programs

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Carnegie Mellon University in 2006.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Three Rivers Second Nature Project Records, 1948-2005, AIS.2006.19B, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence regarding the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. The correspondence is largely general in nature, but includes dialogue from funders and from individuals involved with other greenway or reclamation projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains research data and reports collected regarding the Nine Mile Run Greenway project such as reports, studies, and assessments which were used to aid in the planning process of the area's redevelopment.

did.unittitle: City of Pittsburgh Water department Laboratory
Cooper, Robertson, and Partners Advanced Technology Systems, Inc.
Department of City Planning, City of Pittsburgh
Swisshelm Park Nine Mile Run Development Committee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains financial material directly related to the Nine Mile Run project, such as grant applications and budgets.

Silver Eye Center for Photography, State Water Institute Program, Three Rivers Environmental Awards, and USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains minutes and agendas of the administrators of the Nine Mile Run Greenway project, which documents the evolution of the project from concept to implementation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains information pertaining to two outgrowth projects. The first documents the new housing development called Summerset at Frick Park, a residential neighborhood that was built on top of a slag heap in Nine Mile Run and contains 700 residential housing units. The other project is the Watershed Council which is an organization responsible for the maintenance of the Nine Mile Run Greenway area.

did.unittitle: Watershed Council, Meeting Agendas, Minutes, and Budgets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains material pertaining to outreach presentations and programs designed to get the community invested in the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. Themes included are art exhibition material, Carnegie Mellon University class material, contacts, Nine Mile Run cycling material, press releases and newspaper clippings, public presentations, and Reiko Goto K-12 education outreach program. The latter was created to comply with an agreement the Nine Mile Run Project team had with the Pennsylvania Department of Education which stated that the department would act as a state sponsor and facilitator of the project if a member of the project team would act as a vehicle to train teachers on how to incorporate environmental education into a regular classroom. This educational residency lasted for one year.

did.unittitle: Reiko Goto K - 12 Education Outreach Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains material used for project planning, including drafts, plans, and recommendations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains reference material used throughout the duration of the project, such as pieces of legislation, journal articles, and bound publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains pieces of legislation that were referenced by the administrators of the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. The legislation found here includes serveral levels of government entities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains loose articles that were referenced by the administrators of the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. The material was predominately pulled from professional journals and consists of photocopies and material printed from online resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains bound publications that were referenced by the administrators of the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. The material is professionally published by either a federal agency or a publication company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains workshop material created during the Nine Mile Run Greenway project, and is divided into three subseries by the name of the individual programs: Ample Opportunity I, Ample Opportunity II, and Ample Opportunity III. The workshops included panel discussions by experts in specific areas such as history, public policy, stream remediation, ecology and brownfields. The public was invited to attend these discussions which were followed by opportunities for small group discussions and gathering of information from attendees. This interaction facilitated the collection of oral histories and documents related to the historical usage of the Nine Mile Run watershed region.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material relating to Ample Opportunity I: Community Dialogue. Ample Opportunity I lasted from January 1997 to December 1997 and consisted of four workshops and a greenway tour.

did.unittitle: Workshop I: History, Context, and Public Policy
Workshop III: Slag, Soil, Plants, and Wildlife or Community and Ecology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material relating to Ample Opportunity II: Brownfield Intervention. Ample Opportunity II lasted from January 1998 to December 1998 and created material pertaining the following topics: Bioblitz, Clean-up day, Community meetings, storm water management/Charette project, and summary material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material relating to Ample Opportunity III: The Transformation. Ample Opportunity III lasted from January 1999 to January 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains audio-visual material that was created by the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. The types of media present in this series include photographs, photographic negatives, slides, VHS tapes, videocassette tapes, audio tapes, hard drives, discs (CD-ROM), and floppy disks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains 15 folders of photographic material that document the Nine Mile Run Greenway Project between 1996-1999, and are broken down into four main topics: Tours and Events; Slag, Vegetation, Wildlife, Soil Testing; Stream, Pipes, Aquatic Organisms, Water Testing, Riparian, Erosion, Wetlands; and Trailer, History, 3D Model, Car Burning, Old Brownsfield Road, Mouth of River, Duck Hollow. This organization is reflective of the original structure that was found when the items were donated (4 binders with corresponding titles).

did.unittitle: Binder II: "Slag, Vegetation, Wildlife, Soil Testing"
Binder III: "Stream, Pipes, Aquatic Organisms, Water Testing, Riparian, Erosion, Wetlands"
Binder IV: "Trailer, History, 3D Model, Car Burning, Old Brownsfield Road, Mouth of River, Duck Hollow"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains projection slides that were used to both document the Nine Mile Run Project and for programs. This organization is reflective of the original structure that was found when the items were donated; there were multiple partitioned binders with each section titled one of the ten topics. These items are predominately undated.

did.unittitle: Binder II: "EPA Test Pits, Greenhouse' [slides and prints]
Binder VIII: "Slag, Vegetation, Wildlife, Soil Testing"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains maps that were used during the Nine Mile Run Greenway project. The "Ledger Sized" maps consist mainly of maps with their printed reports concerning population, waste water run-off, pedestrian routes, and tributaries related to the Nine Mile Run site. The oversized maps are housed in five separate file-folders. Of note is the neighborhoods map folder that shows the Nine Mile Run Greenway neighborhood borders and the municipality that is responsible for the various sections of the Nine Mile Run Greenway area. The neighborhoods portrayed include, but are not limited to, the City of Pittsburgh, Swissvale, Edgewood, and Wilkinsburg.
